raw_text:
WMC profits up amid bid criticism
 
 Australian mining firm WMC Resources has seen a fivefold rise in profits while continuing to be the target of a hostile takeover bid.
 
 WMC said it made net profits of 1.33bn Australian dollars ($1bn; £550m) in 2004, up from A$246bn the year before. It is currently arguing against an offer from Swiss Xstrata, which the firm raised to A$8.4bn last week after WMC said it was an undervaluation. Now reports say that the Australian government is against the deal.
 
 Trade Minister Mark Vaile has said that the bid may be "against the national interest". Mr Vaile, who was quoted in the Australian Financial Review, compared Xstrata's attempt to take over WMC to a similar bid by oil giant Shell for Australia's Woodside Petroleum in 2001. The bid was thrown out by Treasurer Peter Costello on national interest grounds. WMC's interests in uranium deposits were a contributing factor, Mr Vaile said. WMC itself, however, has no objection in principle to being bought out, having spun off its aluminium operations in 2002 to make itself a more tempting target - as long as the price is right. Its stellar performance in 2004 has been built on sky-high prices for metals. Copper and nickel in particular have been in high demand thanks to China's booming economy, which expanded more than 9% in each of the past two years. Nickel prices rose 43% during the year, with copper up 36%.
llama3.2:1b: WMC Resources made a fivefold rise in profits to $1bn in 2004 and currently argues against an offer from Swiss Xstrata worth A$8.4bn, citing concerns over national interest.
The Australian government is reportedly opposing the deal.
llama3.2:3b: Australian mining firm WMC Resources made net profits of $1bn in 2004, a fivefold rise from the previous year.
The company is being targeted by a hostile takeover bid from Swiss Xstrata and has raised its value to $8.4bn.
The Australian government, led by Trade Minister Mark Vaile, opposes the deal, citing national interest grounds, particularly WMC's uranium deposits.
gemma2:2b: WMC Resources saw a fivefold increase in profits in 2004 and is facing a hostile takeover bid from Swiss Xstrata.
The Australian government has expressed concerns about the deal, citing potential national interest implications, similar to Shell's failed attempt to acquire Woodside Petroleum.
WMC itself supports being acquired under certain price conditions, believing it allows for a more attractive target.
This strong performance is largely attributed to high metal prices fueled by China's robust economic growth.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Australian mining firm WMC Resources reported a fivefold increase in profits this year while opposing a hostile takeover bid from Swiss Xstrata, which was initially under threat due to concerns about the national interest.
The firm has stated its preference for being purchased at an "undervaluation" compared to Xstrata's offer of A$8.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Australian mining firm WMC Resources reported a fivefold increase in profits from A$246 billion to $1 billion in net profits of AU$1.33 billion for 2004 amid criticism from both Xstrata and Australian government over a potential hostile takeover bid.

The company, which has been under pressure due to an offer worth AU$8.4 billion by Swiss multinational Xstrata, is facing opposition from the Australian government regarding the deal's national interest implications.
WMC, while not objecting in principle, views its uranium deposits as a factor in preferring a high price for being acquired.
The firm has seen significant growth attributed to increasing demand for metals like copper and nickel due to China's economic expansion, with prices rising 43% and 36% respectively over the year.
qwen2.5:3b: Australian mining firm WMC Resources saw a fivefold rise in profits to A$1.33bn in 2004.
However, it continues to face a hostile takeover bid from Swiss Xstrata valued at A$8.4bn, which WMC disputes as undervalued.
The Australian government opposes the deal, citing national interest concerns similar to those raised by former Treasurer Peter Costello against Shell's Woodside Petroleum bid in 2001.
Despite its aluminium operations being spun off in 2002 for easier acquisition, WMC does not object to potential takeover as long as a fair price is offered.
The firm’s success was driven by high metal prices, particularly copper and nickel benefiting from China’s strong economic growth.
opencoder:1.5b: The Australian mining firm WMC Resources has seen a fivefold rise in profits amid bid criticism due to net profits of 1.33bn Australian dollars in 2004 which was up from A$246bn the year before.
The Australian government is against the deal and reports say that the Australian government is against the deal.

WMC said it made net profits of A$1bn (£550m) in 2004, up from A$246bn the year before.
It is currently arguing against an offer from Swiss Xstrata, which the firm raised to A$8.4bn last week after WMC said it was an undervaluation.
Now reports say that the Australian government is against the deal.
Trade Minister Mark Vaile has said that the bid may be "against the national interest".
Mr Vaile, who was quoted in the Australian Financial Review, compared Xstrata's attempt to take over WMC to a similar bid by oil giant Shell for Australia's Woodside Petroleum in 2001.
The bid was thrown out by Treasurer Peter Costello on national interest grounds.
WMC's interests in uranium deposits were a contributing factor, Mr Vaile said.
WMC itself, however, has no objection in principle to being bought out, having spun off its aluminium operations in 2002 to make itself a more tempting target - as long as the price is right.
Its stellar performance in 2004 has been built on sky-high prices for metals.
Copper and nickel in particular have been in high demand thanks to China's booming economy, which expanded more than 9% in each of the past two years.
Nickel prices rose 43% during the year, with copper up 36%.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: WMC Resources experienced a significant increase in profits, rising fivefold from $246 billion to $1.33 billion in 2004, while defending against a hostile takeover bid from Xstrata.
The company argued their valuation was undervaluation at $8.4 billion.
Australian government opposition is expected, with WMC planning to spin off aluminum operations for better targeting.
tinyllama:1.1b:
AWS Launches App Store, Providing a Unified Experience for Amazon's Cloud Services
 
In a move to provide a more seamless experience for its customers, Amazon Web Services (AWS) has launched the AWS App Store.
This new app marketplace will offer developers and businesses an integrated set of services that can be used across multiple cloud platforms.
The platform will make it easier for developers to build solutions using AWS's suite of products and services.
The AWS App Store is the latest addition to Amazon's growing portfolio of cloud-based tools, which includes AWS Cloud9, AWS CodeCommit, and AWS CodeDeploy.
These platforms allow developers to build, test, and deploy their applications with ease using a variety of programming languages and frameworks.
"AWS App Store provides a single point of access for customers to use the full range of AWS services and tools, including the popular AWS Lambda service," said Andy Jassy, CEO of Amazon Web Services.
"By simplifying the way customers use AWS, we can provide even more value to our customers' applications and help them build innovative new solutions."
AWS App Store has already been rolled out in beta form for select groups of developers and businesses.
It will eventually be available to all AWS customers.
This news comes at a time when Amazon is making significant investments in its cloud infrastructure and software offerings to help businesses grow and compete in the digital age.
In June, the company announced that it was tripling its investment in serverless computing with the launch of AWS Lambda Functions.
The announcement followed the company's launch of Amazon API Gateway, which enables developers to build and deploy APIs using a simple set of building blocks.
AWS is also continuing to expand into new markets by offering services in areas such as artificial intelligence (AI) and natural language processing (NLP).
For example, in June, the company announced that it was launching an AI-powered service for detecting and preventing cyber attacks.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Australian mining firm WMC Resources has reported a significant rise in profits, making a net profit of A$1.33 billion ($1 billion; £550 million) in 2004 compared to A$246 billion the year before.

The company's shares have risen significantly since the takeover attempt by Swiss mining giant Xstrata, with WMC now asking for an increased offer of A$8.4 billion, a move that would value the company at around $550 million ($550 million).
The Australian government has expressed concerns over the proposed acquisition, arguing it may compromise national interests and could also impact the market for WMC's uranium assets.
In response to these concerns, WMC itself is considering selling its aluminum operations to generate funds to support its growth plans.

However, it remains committed to being the target of any takeover bid, stating that its performance in 2004 and its strong stance on national interests have made it an attractive target for prospective buyers.
phi:2.7b: WMC Resources saw a fivefold increase in profits while facing a hostile takeover bid by Swiss Xstrata.
The Australian government is opposing the deal and comparing it to previous attempts by Shell and Woodside Petroleum, which were rejected due to national interest concerns.
Despite having no objection in principle to being bought out, WMC has high-value assets that make it an attractive target.
orca-mini:3b: WMC Resources, an Australian mining firm, has seen a fivefold rise in profits while continuing to be the target of a hostile takeover bid.
The company's net profits increased from A$246bn in 2003 to A$1.33bn in 2004, due to high demand for metals such as copper and nickel.
However, the Australian government is reportedly against the deal, with Trade Minister Mark Vaile saying that the bid may be "against the national interest".
The company's decision to spin off its aluminium operations in 2002 helped make it a more attractive target.
hermes3:3b: WMC Resources' profits increase 5x while opposing hostile takeover bid from Swiss Xstrata; Australian government considers deal against national interest.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Australian mining firm WMC Resources reported a 5x increase in profits to A$1bn ($550m) in 2004, amid criticism of a hostile takeover bid from Swiss Xstrata.
The Australian government, including Trade Minister Mark Vaile, is opposed to the deal due to national interest considerations.
WMC has no objection to being bought out, having spun off its aluminum operations in 2002 to make itself more attractive.
High demand for metals, particularly copper and nickel, contributed to WMC's strong performance.
chatgpt-4o-latest: WMC Resources reported a fivefold increase in net profits to A$1.33bn in 2004, driven by high metal prices, particularly copper and nickel, amid strong demand from China's booming economy.
Meanwhile, the company is resisting a hostile takeover bid from Swiss firm Xstrata, which recently raised its offer to A$8.4bn, a valuation WMC disputes.
The Australian government is reportedly against the deal, with Trade Minister Mark Vaile suggesting it may be against national interest, citing concerns over WMC’s uranium deposits.
While WMC is open to a buyout, it insists on an appropriate price.
stablelm2:1.6b: Australian mining firm WMC Resources saw a fivefold increase in profits, reaching A$1bn ($1bn) in net income for 2004, despite being the target of a hostile takeover bid from Swiss Xstrata.

Despite raising its offer to A$8.4bn, the Australian government opposed the deal, with Trade Minister Mark Vaile comparing Xstrata's bid to Shell's unsuccessful attempt at Woodside Petroleum in 1997 due to uranium deposits in WMC's portfolio being a contributing factor.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Australian mining company WMC Resources reported a significant fivefold increase in profits to A$1.33 billion (approximately $1 billion) in 2004, following a challenging previous year.
Despite this strong financial performance, WMC is under a hostile takeover bid from Swiss firm Xstrata, which WMC believes to be an undervaluation at A$8.4 billion.

The Australian government opposes the deal, with Trade Minister Mark Vaile stating it could harm national interests due to WMC's uranium deposits and a comparison to Xstrata's failed 2001 bid for Woodside Petroleum.
WMC has expressed no objection in principle to being acquired, having already spun off its aluminium operations in 2002 to become a more attractive target.
The company's robust performance in 2004 was driven by high metal prices, particularly copper (up 36%) and nickel (rising 43%), fueled by China's rapid economic growth.
